metadata.titleEn: CCropLand30: High-resolution hybrid cropland maps of China
metadata.description: Accurate information on the extents and dynamics of croplands is crucial to address the twin challenges of meeting the growing food needs while reducing environmental footprint. Despite the availability of numerous global and regional cropland maps, significant uncertainties and discrepancies persist in terms of overall area and spatial distribution. In this study, we developed high-resolution hybrid cropland maps of China (CCropLand30) by integrating state-of-the-art remote sensing land use and land cover products (i.e., GlobeLand30, GLAD, CLUD, CLCD, and CACD) with the latest national land survey (NLDS). To this end, we proposed a cost-effective data-fusion approach, namely the majority voting-fuzzy agreement score (MV-FAS) method. The accuracy of CCropLand30 and the input cropland maps was evaluated using both visually interpreted and third-party samples, along with county-level NLDS data. CCropLand30 attains an overall accuracy, Kappa coefficient, and F1-score of 0.88, 0.76, and 0.86, respectively, for the year circa 2020. It demonstrates better agreement with the reference points compared to the input cropland maps, resulting in an enhancement in overall accuracy ranging 10-30%. Moreover, CCropLand30 shows superior spatial consistency with the NLDS data, achieving an average improvement in spatial pattern efficiency by 25%.
metadata.instructions: The hybrid cropland product is stored in TIFF format, and the file is named "CN_crop_merge_yyyy.tif," where yyyy represents the year. For example, CN_crop_merge_2000.tif describes the cropland distribution in China around the year 2000. In the file, the value "1" represents cropland, and "0" represents non-cropland.

background: Accurate information on the extents and dynamics of croplands is crucial to address the twin challenges of meeting the growing food needs while reducing environmental footprint. Despite the availability of numerous global and regional cropland maps, significant uncertainties and discrepancies persist in terms of overall area and spatial distribution. Satellite observations provide great opportunities for long-term and large-scale mapping of croplands in a spatially explicit and cost-effective manner. Over the past two decades, a large number of global and regional land use/land cover (LULC) products have been developed utilizing medium to coarse resolution remote sensing data. However, most remote sensing products do not prioritize cropland mapping and have to balance various LULC classes in one mapping approach, which may deteriorate the accuracy of the resulting cropland maps. Moreover, such kinds of data are unable to identify small field patches due to the medium to coarse spatial resolution. In recent years, the increasing availability of high-resolution remote sensing data (e.g., Landsat and Sentinel-2) and cloud computing platforms has facilitated extensive efforts to create fine-resolution LULC products. Despite these advancements, considerable uncertainties and inconsistencies persist in cropland maps when compared spatially, both in terms of overall area and spatial distribution. These discrepancies arise from the diversity and complexity of agricultural systems, differences in cropland definitions, classification techniques, source data, and the spectral similarity with grassland. Reliable and high-resolution cropland maps are of utmost importance to China, as it sustains 20% of the world's population with only 8% of the global cropland.
research objective: In this study, we developed high-resolution hybrid cropland maps of China (CCropLand30) by integrating state-of-the-art remote sensing land use and land cover products (i.e., GlobeLand30, GLAD, CLUD, CLCD, and CACD) with the latest national land survey (NLDS). The major contributions of this study are threefold. Firstly, we introduced a bias-insensitive spatial pattern matching metric to evaluate and rank the accuracy of satellite-derived cropland maps. Second, a majority voting-fuzzy agreement score (MV-FAS) method was proposed to fuse multiple remote sensing cropland maps with cropland survey data. Lastly, we created high-resolution and reliable hybrid cropland maps for China by synergistically combining state-of-the-art LULC products with China’s latest national land survey (NLDS). Our newly developed hybrid cropland maps will greatly support cropland monitoring and management, as well as research in diverse fields such as agriculture, water resources, and climate change.
challenges: Despite the availability of numerous global and regional cropland maps, significant uncertainties and discrepancies persist in terms of overall area and spatial distribution. These discrepancies arise from the diversity and complexity of agricultural systems, differences in cropland definitions, classification techniques, source data, and the spectral similarity with grassland. The selection of suitable cropland map for specific applications poses significant challenges, potentially bringing large uncertainties to the findings of downstream studies. Most of the data-synergy methods require considerable reference data for model training and validation, and meanwhile, the fusion results can be sensitive to the size and representativeness of the training samples. Ensuring the quality and consistency of the samples is challenging due to the varying domain knowledge of the contributors.
methods: Our methodology began with the generation of a cropland agreement map by combining the cropland binary maps derived from the selected remote sensing LULC products. Next, the NLDS-reported cropland area was adjusted by incorporating the ridge field area estimates from a random forest model. We then proceeded with a spatial-pattern-oriented assessment and ranking of the candidate cropland maps by using a bias-insensitive and multicomponent spatial pattern matching metric (i.e., SPAEF). Subsequently, the hybrid cropland maps were created by integrating remote sensing cropland maps with the NLDS data through a novel MV-FAS approach. In the fifth step, we evaluated the accuracy of the hybrid cropland maps and the input maps using both visually interpreted and third-party reference points (> 8000). Finally, we investigated the spatiotemporal dynamics of croplands in China during the 2000–2020 period using the newly developed cropland maps.
dataset: As listed in Table 1, we selected five state-of-the-art remote sensing LULC products to create hybrid cropland maps of China. These products include GlobeLand30, global cropland extent and change dataset (GLAD), China’s Land-use/cover data set (CLUD), China’s annual land cover dataset (CLCD), and China’s annual cropland dataset (CACD). Our selection was mainly based on the following criteria: (1) the products were developed within the last decade; (2) the products should have a spatial resolution of about 30 m; and (3) the products should cover multiple time periods spanning from 2000 to 2020.
findings: CCropLand30 attains an overall accuracy, Kappa coefficient, and F1-score of 0.88, 0.76, and 0.86, respectively, for the year circa 2020. It demonstrates better agreement with the reference points compared to the input cropland maps, resulting in an enhancement in overall accuracy ranging 10–30%. Moreover, CCropLand30 shows superior spatial consistency with the NLDS data, achieving an average improvement in spatial pattern efficiency by 25%. The CCropLand30 product reveals a clear decreasing trend in China’s cropland area from 2000 to 2020. The area of cropland reduced significantly in relatively water-abundant regions but expanded notably in arid and semi-arid regions with scarce water resources, raising concerns about the spatial mismatch between water and land resources in China.

Definition.Question: What is the 'majority voting-fuzzy agreement score (MV-FAS)' method in the context of data collection?
Definition.Answer: The 'majority voting-fuzzy agreement score (MV-FAS)' method is a data fusion technique used to combine multiple remote sensing cropland maps with cropland survey data to create high-resolution and reliable hybrid cropland maps.

Definition.Question: What does 'bias-insensitive spatial pattern matching metric' mean in the context of evaluating cropland maps?
Definition.Answer: A 'bias-insensitive spatial pattern matching metric' refers to a method used to evaluate and rank the accuracy of satellite-derived cropland maps by assessing their spatial patterns without being affected by biases.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'high-resolution hybrid cropland maps' in the context of land use and cover products?
Definition.Answer: 'High-resolution hybrid cropland maps' refer to detailed maps that are created by integrating various state-of-the-art remote sensing land use and land cover products with national land survey data, providing accurate and spatially consistent information on cropland extents and dynamics.

Comparison.Question: How does the majority voting-fuzzy agreement score (MV-FAS) method for fusing multiple remote sensing cropland maps compare to traditional data-synergy methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency?
Comparison.Answer: The MV-FAS method is designed to economically and effectively fuse multiple remote sensing cropland maps with cropland survey data. It addresses significant uncertainties and discrepancies present in existing global and regional cropland maps by providing an improvement in overall accuracy by 10-30% when compared to input cropland maps, and enhances spatial consistency with the national land survey data by an average of 25%. Traditional data-synergy methods often require extensive reference data for model training and validation, which can be sensitive to the size and representativeness of the training samples.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges in ensuring quality and consistency of samples in cropland mapping compare to the challenges in selecting suitable cropland maps for specific applications?
Comparison.Answer: Ensuring quality and consistency of samples in cropland mapping is challenging due to the varying domain knowledge of contributors, which affects the representativeness and reliability of the training samples. This impacts the accuracy and consistency of the fusion results. On the other hand, selecting suitable cropland maps for specific applications poses challenges due to significant uncertainties and discrepancies in existing maps, which arise from differences in cropland definitions, classification techniques, and source data. Both challenges can introduce large uncertainties in downstream studies.

Causal Antecedent.Answer: These discrepancies arise from the diversity and complexity of agricultural systems, differences in cropland definitions, classification techniques, source data, and the spectral similarity with grassland.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to ensure the quality and consistency of samples used for model training and validation in cropland mapping?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Ensuring the quality and consistency of the samples is challenging due to the varying domain knowledge of the contributors, which affects the representativeness and size of the training samples used in data-synergy methods.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors have facilitated the creation of fine-resolution land use/land cover products in recent years?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The increasing availability of high-resolution remote sensing data (e.g., Landsat and Sentinel-2) and cloud computing platforms has facilitated extensive efforts to create fine-resolution LULC products.

Causal Consequence.Question: What impact does integrating remote sensing land use and land cover products with national land survey data have on the accuracy of cropland maps?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating remote sensing land use and land cover products with national land survey data enhances the accuracy of cropland maps significantly, as demonstrated by the improved overall accuracy, Kappa coefficient, and F1-score of CCropLand30, which are 0.88, 0.76, and 0.86, respectively. This integration results in a 10-30% improvement in overall accuracy compared to input cropland maps.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a majority voting-fuzzy agreement score method for fusing multiple remote sensing cropland maps?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a majority voting-fuzzy agreement score method for fusing multiple remote sensing cropland maps can result in high-resolution and reliable hybrid cropland maps. This method enables the creation of maps that are more consistent with reference points and national land survey data, thereby enhancing spatial pattern efficiency by an average of 25%.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the driving goals behind integrating multiple remote sensing land use and cover products with national land survey data to create a high-resolution cropland map?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to develop reliable and high-resolution cropland maps that accurately reflect cropland extents and dynamics, reduce uncertainties and discrepancies present in existing maps, and support cropland monitoring and management, as well as research in agriculture, water resources, and climate change.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the use of a majority voting-fuzzy agreement score (MV-FAS) method in the creation of a cropland dataset?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The MV-FAS method is employed to effectively fuse multiple remote sensing cropland maps with cropland survey data, thereby enhancing the accuracy and spatial consistency of the resulting hybrid cropland maps. This approach aims to overcome the limitations of individual datasets and provide a comprehensive and reliable depiction of cropland areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in creating a high-resolution cropland map using remote sensing data and national land survey data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To create a high-resolution cropland map, the process begins with generating a cropland agreement map by combining binary maps derived from selected remote sensing LULC products. The next step involves adjusting the NLDS-reported cropland area using ridge field area estimates from a random forest model. Following this, a spatial-pattern-oriented assessment and ranking of candidate cropland maps using a bias-insensitive spatial pattern matching metric (SPAEF) are conducted. The hybrid cropland maps are then created by integrating these remote sensing maps with NLDS data through the MV-FAS approach. Finally, the accuracy of these maps is evaluated using visually interpreted and third-party reference points.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the MV-FAS method be utilized to improve the accuracy and spatial consistency of cropland maps?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The MV-FAS method improves accuracy and spatial consistency by fusing multiple remote sensing cropland maps with cropland survey data. This method involves majority voting and fuzzy agreement scoring, which helps in resolving discrepancies and enhancing the consistency of the cropland maps through the integration of diverse data sources that account for different spatial and temporal scales.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges arise when selecting suitable cropland maps for specific applications, and how can these be addressed procedurally?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include significant uncertainties and discrepancies in cropland maps due to varying agricultural systems, definitions, classification techniques, source data, and spectral similarities with grassland. Procedurally, these can be addressed by using data-synergy methods that require substantial reference data for training and validation. Ensuring the quality and consistency of samples is crucial, which can be achieved by leveraging domain knowledge and maintaining the representativeness of training samples.

Enablement.Question: What are the key data fusion methods that enable the integration of multiple remote sensing cropland maps for improved accuracy?
Enablement.Answer: The key data fusion method mentioned is the majority voting-fuzzy agreement score (MV-FAS) method, which integrates multiple remote sensing cropland maps with cropland survey data to create high-resolution and reliable hybrid cropland maps.

Enablement.Answer: Advancements in remote sensing technology, such as the increasing availability of high-resolution data from sources like Landsat and Sentinel-2, along with cloud computing platforms, facilitate extensive efforts to create fine-resolution land use/land cover products.

Enablement.Question: What selection criteria enable the identification of suitable remote sensing LULC products for creating high-resolution cropland maps?
Enablement.Answer: The selection criteria for suitable remote sensing LULC products include development within the last decade, a spatial resolution of about 30 meters, and coverage of multiple time periods from 2000 to 2020.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of integrating multiple remote sensing LULC products with national land survey data in improving the accuracy of cropland maps?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of multiple remote sensing LULC products with national land survey data is considered effective in improving the accuracy of cropland maps. It allows for the creation of high-resolution and reliable hybrid cropland maps by synergistically combining various state-of-the-art products with the latest national survey data, leading to greater consistency with reference points and improved spatial pattern efficiency.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of cropland maps when using diverse remote sensing data sources?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential challenges in ensuring accuracy and reliability of cropland maps include significant uncertainties and discrepancies arising from the diversity and complexity of agricultural systems, differences in cropland definitions, classification techniques, source data, and spectral similarity with grassland. Additionally, the requirement for considerable reference data for model training and validation, and sensitivity of fusion results to the size and representativeness of training samples pose further challenges.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the key considerations for selecting remote sensing LULC products to develop high-resolution cropland datasets in China?
Judgmental.Answer: Key considerations for selecting remote sensing LULC products include ensuring the products have been developed within the last decade, having a spatial resolution of approximately 30 meters, and covering multiple time periods spanning from 2000 to 2020. These criteria help in creating hybrid cropland maps that are comprehensive, up-to-date, and able to reflect temporal changes effectively.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a data collection method that integrates multiple remote sensing LULC products with national land survey data to improve cropland mapping accuracy.

This method combines cropland maps derived from satellite observations with the latest national land survey data to create high-resolution hybrid cropland maps, enhancing spatial consistency and accuracy.

Additionally, the fusion results can be sensitive to the size and representativeness of training samples, and ensuring quality is challenging due to varying domain knowledge among contributors.
